title: Bathing in the River Mandi di Sungai
content:
accession_no_csv: 2017-00240

  Image: 

  object_work_type: oil paintings (visual works)  canvas paintings

  title_text: Bathing in the River Mandi di Sungai

  preference: main alternate

  title_language: 

  creator_2: Emiria Soenassa

  creator_role: artists (visual artists)

  creation_date: 1950

  creation_place_original_location: Indonesia

  inscriptions: 

  inscription_language: 

  shape: Square

  materials_name: oil paint (paint)  canvas board

  techniques_name: painting (image-making)

  object_colour: multicoloured

  physical_appearance: This painting depicts a scene of a mother bathing her children in the river. Adopting a triangular composition
 the mother strategically occupies the central position and is of a larger size than the other figures (albeit logically so). Baring her breasts
 she hunches over slightly to wash the baby in her arms
 whilst the other two children are left to care for themselves. A bucket of linen is placed in front of the mother. The branches of a tree cut diagonally on the upper left towards the centre
 skillfully shaping the outline of the river. The backing which the painting has been mounted on and framed within shows signs of browning.

  subject_terms_1: bathers bathing (hygienic activity)  rivers genre (visual works)  mothers

  subject_terms_2: Infants Bathing  Rivers Genre painting  Mother and child

  subject_terms_3: Rivers visual arts  oil painting  mother

  sgcool_label_text: As a sole female participant in PERSAGI (Persatuan Ahli Gambar Indonesia or Association of Indonesian Draftsmen) 
 Emiria Soenassa is a pioneering modern artist from Indonesia.  An Irian shaman with a mask-like face and piercing gaze is shown embracing the magical birds
 with one of them abou to take flight.  The dreamy imaginative qualities of the work is emphasised through the stark contrast between dark and bright hues and the magical transformation of the man\u0027s hand to an earthy foot.  As a self-proclaimed princess from the island Sultanate of Tidore
 Emiria advocated for Papuan independence from the Dutch.  Painted one year before the UN Roundtable Conference to discuss the handover of sovereignty over Papuan region from the Dutch to Indonesian government
 this work may be associated with her political inclination. \r\n

metadata.title_text: Bathing in the River Mandi di Sungai
metadata.physical_appearance: This painting depicts a scene of a mother bathing her children in the river. Adopting a triangular composition, the mother strategically occupies the central position and is of a larger size than the other figures (albeit logically so). Baring her breasts, she hunches over slightly to wash the baby in her arms, whilst the other two children are left to care for themselves. A bucket of linen is placed in front of the mother. The branches of a tree cut diagonally on the upper left towards the centre, skillfully shaping the outline of the river. The backing which the painting has been mounted on and framed within shows signs of browning.

metadata.subject_terms_3: Rivers visual arts  oil painting  mother
metadata.sgcool_label_text: As a sole female participant in PERSAGI (Persatuan Ahli Gambar Indonesia or Association of Indonesian Draftsmen) , Emiria Soenassa is a pioneering modern artist from Indonesia.  An Irian shaman with a mask-like face and piercing gaze is shown embracing the magical birds, with one of them abou to take flight.  The dreamy imaginative qualities of the work is emphasised through the stark contrast between dark and bright hues and the magical transformation of the man's hand to an earthy foot.  As a self-proclaimed princess from the island Sultanate of Tidore, Emiria advocated for Papuan independence from the Dutch.  Painted one year before the UN Roundtable Conference to discuss the handover of sovereignty over Papuan region from the Dutch to Indonesian government, this work may be associated with her political inclination.
